elements.title: Raphael de Mercatellis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the library of Raphael de Mercatellis (coat of arms pictured) was the first library in the Low Countries to "reveal an extensive interest in what we may call Renaissance ideas"?

elements.title: a song about murdering her ex-boyfriend (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Kill Bill films inspired SZA to write a song about murdering her ex-boyfriend?

elements.title: Sergio Salomón Céspedes (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the president of his own party criticized the speed at which members of the Congress of Puebla moved to appoint Sergio Salomón Céspedes as the substitute governor?

elements.title: Stephen Furness (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the luxury passenger steamer Stephen Furness was taken into Royal Navy service during the First World War and was sunk by a U-boat, with the loss of more than 100 lives?

elements.title: Pap of Armenia (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Pap of Armenia survived an assassination attempt by Roman legions during a battle, but was later murdered by the Romans during a feast?

elements.title: Communist Opposition (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Communist Opposition was the most popular slate in the 1931 Czechoslovak municipal election in Unhošť?

elements.title: Emerson Charles Denny (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that American professor Emerson Charles Denny co-published the Nelson–Denny Reading Test in 1930, which has parts held at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History?

elements.title: Judge Lu (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that according to Ren Xiaoping, the first reference to a body swap occurs in the Chinese short story "Judge Lu", in which the titular character performs a head transplant on his friend's wife?
